newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Clean sweep for UK virus killer at Easdaq start.
newsitem.headline: Clean sweep for UK virus killer at Easdaq start.

text.p: Europe's newest stock market, Easdaq, on Wednesday finally went live as shares in the first company to be listed on it, a British-based anti-virus software developer, began trading.
Dr Solomon's Group Plc won the race to kick off the screen-based action on the pan-European growth stocks exchange, modelled on the Nasdaq in New York.
"It has been satisfactory for a first day," Easdaq spokesman Chris Pickles said. "The system has held up and prices (for Dr Solomon's) stayed stable."

Easdaq -- the European Association of Securities Dealers Automated Quotations System -- expects to see a dozen shares traded by the end of January and up to 50 by the end of 1997 with a target of 500 companies listed in the next five years.
Easdaq became technically operational on September 30, but the rules were not published until late October.
Dr Solomon's stock opened at $17, saw some action between $17-1/8 and $16-7/8, and stood at $17 again at the close. Volume had reached 17,775 shares by then.
Easdaq's trading hours are 9:30 a.m. (0830 GMT) to 4:30 p.m. 1530 GMT). The exchange has offices in Brussels and London.
Dr Solomon's is also listed on Nasdaq in the United States, as are other candidate stocks. On Nasdaq the stock was also quoted at $17 on Wednesday afternoon.
Dr Solomon's planned to raise about $96 million to reach total market capitalisation of about $300 million.
Pickles said the stock had seen trade throughout the European Union. "As expected trades were done across borders."
The hi-tech company is one of many entrepreneurial growth companies that Easdaq is aiming for.
Pipped to the post by Dr Solomon's, Belgian biotechnology firm Innogenetics is due to start trading on Easdaq on Thursday after an initial public offering.
It hopes to raise $78 million to achieve a market capitalisation of about $246 million. Shares in its initial public offering, five times oversubscribed, are priced at $12.
French "smart card" maker ActivCard SA and Belgian printers software firm Artwork Systems aim to list on Easdaq in early December.

Another candidate emerged on Wednesday. French low-cost flat screen technology firm PixTech, already listed on Nasdaq, said it aimed to raise 100 million French francs via Easdaq at the beginning of December.
Easdaq is a rival of the Euro NM exchange for small- and medium-sized companies. The Nouveau Marche project involves the Brussels, Frankfurt, Paris and Amsterdam bourses.

Easdaq's Pickles highlighted the differences between the two projects. "We don't see it as a competitor, (Euro NM) is not pan-European, it is (a market) for companies from those countries within those countries."
Easdaq, by contrast, was aimed at international investors and for internationally oriented companies, he said.
The Easdaq project originated from contacts between the European Venture Capital Association, the European Commission and various market players.
Nasdaq is one of Easdaq's 91 shareholders which brought about 370 million Belgian francs together to finance its launch.
